I've visited this In-N-Out twice in the past year and both times it was so crowded that I just couldn't relax to eat. Granted, it is in a very touristy area and it was lunchtime, so I suppose I can't really complain. 

That said, the second time I visited (April 2009), I had a Double-Double protein-style (wrapped in lettuce). That helped bring out more of the burger flavor. I just wish their burgers were served hot instead of "kind of" warm. 

After hearing about this place for years, I thought the experience would be better. But I guess that's the problem with hype. 

And where's the bathroom?
author: Amanda D.

description:
Crowded, but there just people standing around for no reason.

Looks exactly like a McDonalds..

The food was good.
author: Kwame J.

description:
What can I saw about In-N-Out that hasn't been said before?

In-N-Out is a staple in my diet- It is a category unto itself in my personal food pyramid.

While Fisherman's Wharf isn't exactly a convenient location, it is still totally worth the ride on the F line or cable car.

I am such a sucker for their animal-style cheeseburgers, and I recently discovered they will make a ROOT BEER FLOAT for you! I love how minimal the menu is too- it makes decision making a necessity of the past.

Also! They are open until 1am Sun-Thurs and 1:30am on Friday and Saturday!!!


Beautiful!!!!!!
author: Felicity M.

description:
I'm from Colorado and visiting California, I finally got a chance to try the famous "In-N-Out Burger," the much-hyped burger chain.

The burgers might be better than McDonalds, Burger King, or Wendy's, but to me, that is hardly a ringing endorsement. In fact, In-N-Out is basically just like any of these fast food burger places, except with fresher fries and (probably?) better meat.

But it's still incredibly greasy, mostly tasteless, and has a much smaller menu than the aforementioned competitors, where someone can at least opt for a chicken sandwich or a salad.

My first, and hopefully last trip to In-N-Out Burger amounted to standing in a long line and waiting in a crowded restaurant for a greasy pile of food-like product. Ew.
author: Ken K.

description:
I tend to have a very bad weak side to me. I LOVE LOVE burgers, and In-N-Out is just way too irresistible. 

Their burgers are flavorful with their special sauce (sort of a thousand island spin off). I love the fact that you can request the onions grilled, protein style (lettuce wrap: sans bun), or animal style (extra special sauce!).  Oh and If you watch them, they actually slice the whole potatoes for the french fries! 

And since I eat too much I always order a double double with their natural cut fries, and a coke to top it off. On a good day, I love to suck down their milkshakes (thick & creamy). Come to think of it, I once ate TWO double doubles in one sitting. 

Speaking of In-N-Out their service seems to always be quick & friendly despite this location being busy most of the time. Never a long wait, and the true definition of fast food. It takes longer to find a seat to sit, than to get your food! 

By the way if you're feeling daring they have animal style fries (their fries drizzling in a mound of their special sauce!). And if you need the bathroom, it's outside. 

Oooooh gosh I love burgers. Sometimes I wish I WAS one. (~o~  )!
author: Catherine O.

description:
Ehhhhhh.  I don't get it.

This was my first and only time trying In-N-Out and I really don't get the near-psychotic hype for this place. I get that it's supposed to be this amazing burger, but it just tasted like a fast food burger. It wasn't bad...but it really wasn't as amazing as it was supposed to be. There was a bun, meat, cheese, toppings, animal sauce...normal. Fries....normal. Milkshake....normal. I'm probably speaking blasphemy to you all, but I don't think the Big Mac is too far apart from the In-N-Out burger. 

More than anything I was impressed and astounded at the efficiency that was this well-oiled machine. The Monica Gellar in me was excited to watch how quickly and robotically and efficiently all of the employees completed their tasks. 

I'd imagine it would be pretty good drunk food, but isn't any fast food chain good junk food. Next time I visit the west coast, I probably wouldn't go out of my way to seek it out.
author: Joan K.

description: More locations in SF, pleaseeeee! This one is the only one, and it can be a long trek from other parts of SF. I've been two or three times now in the last month. Every time it's fairly crowded, but the service is super quick, and the burgers are on point. Having moved recently from New York, the immediate comparison is with Shake Shack, which has it's own east coast fan following. In-n-out is awesome because you'll always get your food faster than at Shake Shack. Taste-wise, it's plainer because you have less jazzy options, but each ingredient is quality. A Shake Shack burger is tasty burger, but definitely you can taste the grease. Conclusion: If you have an In-n-out burger every day, you'll live longer than if you were to have a Shake Shack burger every day.
author: S L.

description:
A great San Franciscan , I LOVE IN N OUT BURGER

I have been here for year since i was 10 years old and i say it pretty great to custom order ...I gets busy often especially at lunch time. I come about once or twice a month to eat In N Out  ..
author: Eric W.

description: You must try this amazing burger joint.  I worked there for five years and I still love their food.  The workers are very nice and the managers are as well. Try the Root-beer float and the animal fries.
author: Spring C.

description: Very crowded and busy but great service as usual.  Tables are hard to come by so if you must sit try to get there before noon or after lunch rush.  Or sit outside but you are subject to the elements.
author: Dan W.

description: Its in and out burger... what else can I say?!? If you want a good burger and fries for cheap then this is your spot. If you have never been before, its worth a stop in at some point. This place is far from gourmet, but it will hit the spot if you are in the mood for a burger.
author: Shanna T.

description:
Good, now I don't have to go to Daly City for this.  I can stay in town.  I never knew about this In-N-Out in Fishermans Wharf.

I order the #2 Cheeseburger meal.  Of course, I get the cheeseburger "animal style" with their sauce, pickles, and chopped grilled onions all without the bun.  I like it better without the bun, plus you save 200 calories.  Cut corners whenever you can.  The fries are good (not too oily).

I think the prices are a little bit better in Daly City.  But still, even in Fishermans Wharf, I'm a fan of In-N-Out.
author: Janet H.

description:
Craving In-N-Out, I wandered through Chinatown and North Beach until I saw that magical arrow pointing me to the building.  God damn it was packed full of people.  
The line to order moved super quick, but waiting for the order took some time.  Probably the most overworked staff for an In-N-Out I've seen, just a constant rush, but I got my food, a Double Double with grilled onions.  
So cheap and my god it was magic in my mouth.
author: Sam H.

description:
In-N-Out... will you marry me?  

If only my relationships were half as remember-able as your delicious double double waiting for me at 12:30AM underneath that garish red neon sign.

You make me so happy In-N-Out and that's what it's all about.
author: Paul S.

description:
Sub-par branch of the In-N-Out chain.  If you want an In-N-Out fix, go to virtually any other branch in the bay area and you're likely to get better quality.  This was the first In-N-Out I visited after hearing raves about the chain for years, and I was severely disappointed.  I'm not into fast food much, but I can definitely appreciate a tasty fast food greaseburger and fries at the right time.  However, this In-N-Out location was so mediocre it made me wonder what all the ravers were talking about.

Soggy hamburgers, food thrown together too carelessly even for fast food, overall seems below average in its class.  

I think this In-N-Out is worse than others because it caters primarily to Fisherman's Wharf tourists, thus it has devolved to just getting customers, um, in & out the door 1 time, doesn't have to be good food, their goal is to just get the customer's money one time then its "bye, next."  

If you've never been to In-N-Out and want to check them out, do not make this place your first choice because it will give you a bad first impression of the chain.

There are much much better In-N-Outs in the bay area: for example check out the Daly City In-N-Out which I'll review next - now that is some crypt fast food.
author: Jack H.

description: The burgers used to taste different , now the meat seems kinda skimpy
author: Jade H.

description: I mean... It's In N Out... What more needs to be said!? Double double animal style and a strawberry shake!
author: Sam G.

description: I had always heard how good their burgers were so I thought I would try them. I wish I hadn't. I ordered 2 double doubles and an order of fries. The double doubles weren't cooked all the way through and the fries were so raw, it was like taking fries out of a freezer, letting them thaw and then serving them to someone. If this is what all the hype is about, I'm surprised they've been in business this long.
author: Doll O.

description:
I've been to a few locations, but I've been to this one the most so I'll review it. I am an In-N-Out convert. Anytime you see someone using that fancy "french fry making machine straight from the spud" there's a possibility it will be good. And I have to say I'm a connoisseur of "fine" fast food french fries and these are probably the best I've had. The burgers are good too, I don't even pretend to be an a diet when I go here, but see it as a treat. 

This location gets flooded with tourists and it's pretty small too so it probably depends on the time of day and exactly what your level of tolerance is when being in a cramped space with lots of people. However, the significant other and I went here during the week at 11 a.m., best time as they had just opened and we didn't have to fight for a seat. We also went here on July 4 and although I'm sure they had extra hands helping out that day, the line was out the door but in no time we had food in hand. For such a heavily trodded tourist area, I'd visit anytime I need a burger fix.
author: Heather M.

description: I was looking forward to my first in and out burger experience since we don't have those in ohio....and it was just okay.  Inexpensive for good sized portions, but nothing much different than 5 Guys. I also found the service rude in the manner that he demanded I produce a receipt to pick up my food -like I'd pick up on order that isnt mine - after having to stand among annoying loud people when the food was being cooked. I was just kind of glad to get out of there at the end
author: Tracie B.

description: Not the judge or juror just a foodie. This may very well be thee most odd critique I have ever given ...there is a bit of a love hate situation with this place. Let's first discuss the borderline hatred I have for this place......too limited a menu burger , fries, drinks...too crowded....to slow for fast food....too expensive......too basic....and the shakes are too artificially flavored.......NOW... let us discuss what I like about this place.....short to the point menu......a lot of people so food keeps moving.....you know they take their time with your order........the price point is over average so it brings an air of sophistication........bread, meat, cheese, onions lettuce, tomatoes charred and so much flavor especially with grilled onion- basic.....and that strawberry shake was so artificial it tasted like  cotton candy I couldn't stop sipping it , it was almost like molicrakmetheroin I don't know. As you can see the reasons I hate it are the same reasons I liked it .....weird but true....Side note you have to go to this one location we tried one in Reno and it was all bad....this location has the life you like in a crowded eatery, check them out.....Grace and Peace to you guys
author: Robyn L.

description:
Overrated, overrated, overrated. 

What are you thinking, people? I get why frat boys get so excited about names like "animal style" and why Atkins followers would appreciate the "protein" style burgers, but the fries are awful and the burgers are simply plain, edible burgers. Not bad at all, but not living up to their reputation. 

I respect that this company has a reputation for treating its workers well and paying them a living wage. It's a good place to stop if you're craving beef along the highway, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: akimbo j.

description: My first In-N-Out experience! ... I don't usually make these kind of comparisons but this place has nothing on Five Guys. I WILL say, however, that the cheeseburger animal style was kind of amazing. :) The fries were so-so but the service was great. I'm glad I tried it but Five Guys will always hold the cheap burger prize in my heart.
author: Elena M.

description:
The food is delicious and it's different than the same old fast food joint. I am a fan of the burgers, with all the sauce and cheese. 

The thing about this location is it is over filled with tourist. For such a busy place, they should have a bigger dining area. 
I started to get frustrated because of the tourist bumping into me in the line and having me step back and forth so people could get through. The seats were all taken, and we had to eat outside. 

It's nice to see the business doing so well because it's well deserved! I understand why it was so packed with people, because of the great food and tiny prices. 

I am a fan
author: Niki M.

description: I ALWAYS get the animal style fries and cheeseburger! If I'm extra hungry, I upgrade to the double-double and get a neopolitan shake! Not my favorite burger place, but probably my favorite fast food joint. It's a bit inconvenient to get to without a car, but whenever I crave it in SF I hit it up in the wharf.
author: Emmanuel C.

description:
I love In-N-Out. Whenever my friends and I visit from the East Coast, this is the first place we go to when we want to eat something. It's very cheap but really delicious.

Parking is not that great though.
author: Sam Y.

description:
During my collegiate academic career, California natives used to boast this business' greatness and superiority to fast food chains such as McDonald's and Burger King. The word-of-mouth advertising was done with such enthusiasm, I thought my friends had experienced some state of euphoria every time they said, "Double-double animal style with fries".

I've been to this Fisherman's Wharf location a few times over the years. It was my first In-N-Out. I enjoy it, just like everyone else, but seriously, the food is not transcendent. Better than McD, BK, 5 Guys? Yes, the fries are awesome enough to make J.R. Simplot turn in his grave. Sometimes I could go for a Whopper or Big Mac though.

Will I "JIMP" [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4pXfHLUlZf4] every time I eat In-N-Out?

Never.

Sorry friends.

IFHTP 3+
author: Peter K.

description: When I feel like hamburger I will always try to look for IN-N-OUT Burger at whatever neighborhood i am in.  They have the best burger, grill to order not like others burger joint serve you with "per-grilled" patties. Their food always fresh & their fires are using veg oil i guess it mean little healthier :).
author: Charlie H.

description:
Awesome!  Coming from southern California, this used to be a monthly, even weekly staple!  I'm so glad there is one up here, although I've only been here once since moving up here.  At least I know where it is!  There are long lines since it's amongst the tourist attractions, but when you know what the taste of a double-double animal style with well-done fries and a neapolitan shake are like, you know it's worth the wait.  Besides that, did you know about their secret non-published menu?  If not, then here you go!

In-N-Out Burger has a secret unpublished menu for insiders who are in-the-know. Next time you're at In-N-Out (i.e. tomorrow . . . or maybe tonight), order a bag of these off-the-menu specials:

"3-by-3" = three meat patties and three slices of cheese.

"4-by-4" = four meat patties and four slices of cheese.

"2-by-4" = two meat patties and four slices of cheese.

*Note: You may get a burger with the exact number of meat patties or cheese slices you want (up to 4x4). Just tell the In-N-Out Burger cashier how many meat patties and how much cheese you want and that is what you'll get! For instance, if you want 4 pieces of meat and 3 pieces of cheese tell them you want a "4-by-3."

"Double Meat" = like a Double Double without cheese.

"3 by Meat" = three meat patties and no cheese.

"Animal Style" = the meat is cooked and fried with mustard and then pickles are added, extra spread and grilled onions are added.

"Animal Style Fries" = fries with cheese, spread, grilled onions and pickles (if you ask for them).

"Protein Style" = for all you low-carbohydrate dieters, this is a burger with no bun (wrapped in lettuce).

"Flying Dutchman" = two meat patties, two slices of melted cheese and nothing else - not even a bun!

Fries "Well-Done" = extra crispy fries . . . even better than the regular!

Fries "Light" = opposite of fries well-done, more raw than most people like 'em

"Grilled Cheese" = no meat, just melted cheese, tomato, lettuce and spread on a bun.

"Veggie Burger" = burger without the patty or cheese. Sometimes we call this the "Wish Burger."

"Neapolitan" Shake = strawberry, vanilla and chocolate mixed together.

The friendly employees of In-N-Out Burger will take your special order without question, if you use the right terminology. The printed receipt will have your special request typed on it just as we said it.
author: Limzer L.

description:
LINGUISTICS AND LANGUAGE FAMILY HISTORY 201

Good morning.

It is common knowledge that In-N-Out prints Biblical citations from the Old Testament, New Testament, and Apocrypha on their cups and wrappers.

When one remembers that the original languages were Hebrew, Aramaic and Koine Greek, this presents tremendous problems for those of us who wish to understand the true meaning of these citations.

Without getting involved in the endless debate of dynamic equivalence vs. formal equivalence (BLAH BLAH BLAH BLAH), I would like to provide updated translations in the context of In-N-Out.

Revelation 3:20 (Burger and cheeseburger wrappers): 
Behold, I stand at the door, and wait in line for eternity: if any man hear My voice, and open the door, I will buy him a double-double and animal style fries, and he will sup with me. 

John 14:6 (Paper water cups):
Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man grilleth a great Burger, but by me.

Proverbs 3:5 (Milkshake cups):
Trust in Thousand Island dressing with all thine heart; and rely not on the grilled onion. 

Nahum 1:7 (Double-Double wrapper): 
The Kennebec Potato is a strong balm for the day of darkness; and whosoever knoweth the Potato will also knoweth the Fry.
 
John 3:16 (Beverage cups):
For God so loved the world, he maketh burgers fit for a Shepherd and laceth them with crack, that whoever consumeth his patties should not leave hungry, but enjoy everlasting life. 

And that ends today's lesson.
author: d s.

description:
There are several things I will probably never, ever come to understand:

1) Women
2) How Bush got elected not only once, but twice
3) People's love of In-N-Out Burger

When I first moved to LA at the tender age of 17, the first thing people would ask me when they found out I wasn't from SoCal was, "Have you tried In-N-Out yet?" It's like some sort of cult down there. So when they started opening 'em up in the Bay Area a number of years ago, the zombie-like Pavlovian response to each new outlet didn't surprise me.  I see the phenomenon, I just don't understand it.

Listen, I know how important fresh ingredients are. I'm all for freshly ground beef, real ice cream shakes, and house-cut fries. I think it's fantastic that a fast food chain bothers to hand-leaf their lettuce and cut their own tomatoes and onions. I even find the little "John 3:16" imprinted on the bottom rim of their cups cute and endearing in a backwater whitewashed LA suburb kind of way.

BUT FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, COULD YOU PLEASE MAKE IT TASTE GOOD?

Over the years, I've tried every permutation of every item on their menu. Yes, the secret menu, too. Animal style. Fries well done. Protein style. Doggie style. Dipped in worchestershire sauce and marinated in Rosie O'Donnell's cooch style. (That was the worst.) 

They all friggin' suck.

Yet today, out of dire need for a milkshake, I decided to give them another go. I must have the memory of a god damn goldfish.
author: Omid T.

description: Food here is pretty good and consistent. The price is way more experience than any other in and out burger in the bay area. Parking is hard to find around the area.
author: Anthony V.

description:
H- Welcome to In N Out
H- May I take your order?

M- Yes please...
M- 4X4 animal style 
M- along with fries done well animal style
M- excuse my asking......but do you work at hooters too???

no, I didn't ask that...but I was thinking it - hell it's right next door!
author: John-Michael C.

description:
Okay, so I'm from the East Coast.  I'd always assumed In And Out to be similar to the many regional fast food chains from my own life experience--White Castle, Hardee's, Little Tavern, etc.  I expected In And Out to be just total shit and practically unedible swill, so I just never went to one (the location in the Wharf made this especially easy!)  Then, one night at a party at Station 40 I was talking with someone and somehow In And Out burger came up...

Well, does it even need to be said that I couldn't wait to try it?  Secret Menu!  Living wage and benefits for employees!  Crossed Palm tree things at most locations!  Cryptic hidden bible verses on cups!  I absolutely had to go to In and Out, but first I checked out the secret menu on their website so I could be prepared.  It's there I learned that In and Out has a commitment to fresh, quality ingredients, and that's why they're only in Southern California (and a few up here...)  I was down.

On my first visit to In And Out, I prepared myself, walked up the the register and said "Hi, I've never been to In And Out before."  The cashier gets this discernably quizzical look on her face, yet, a look of recognition, and says. "okay..."  I proceed to order a Grilled Cheese, animal style, Animal Fries and a shake.  When she asks what kind of shake I would like, I kind of nerdily hold up a finger, and with what surely must have been a twinkle in my eye, replied "Neopolitan."  I confirmed with her that nothing I ordered had any meat in it, took my number, and sat down and waited.

This great thing happened while I was waiting.  This really tall, lanky black thug dude in one of those oversized white t-shirts (a thug style which started out in BALTIMORE!!!) gets his order filled, snatches it out of the employee's hands and leaves the restaurant yelling "ANIMAL STYYYYYLE... MUTHA FUCKIN' ANIMAAAAAL STYYYYLE!" while pounding his chest with his fist.  I knew, right then, that I had come to the right place.

After about ten minutes or so, my order is ready.  And tasty it was!  Super good, the animal fries were really amazing, perfectly and delecately flavored and, I found out at the end, made with real, fresh potatoes.  The grilled cheese animal style was great, a toasty bun, melty cheese, lettuce, tomatoes, and that thousand island-ish sauce with grilled onions, absolutely perfect.

Then, this second really great thing happened.  I was siting in my cab on Jefferson there, eating my In and Out, and a radio call came in around the corner for Gary Danko Restaurant.  I jammed up Hyde street, pile of fries in my lap, and stopped in front.  As the host came out to let me know the table was paying their bill and would be out momentarily, she commented "boy, it sure does smell good in here..." and I was all "hey I just got some In And Out, first time ever... You want some?"  Her face lights up, and she's like "oh yeah, we all love that place!"  Soon two of the waitstaff are leaning in the side of my cab helping me scarf down the fries.  The irony here is that Danko is one of THE MOST exclusive restaurants in the city, with dinner for two costing like over $200, and here is the staff clamoring over some fries from In And Out and saying how delicious they are.  

These are the moments that make life worth living.
author: Ben V.

description:
Everybody knows what's up with the food here (I had a double double, animal style, fries and a glass of water - it was as it always is) - but who really stops to think about the bathrooms?

In Thailand in restaurant and bar bathrooms, there are these guys who make their living a few cents at a time by giving men shoulder rubs as the men use the urinals.  As a westerner with a very discrete sense of personal space, especially when urinating, I wasn't really into it.  I was warned in advance about this phenomenon, so I usually was alert to their approach and I was able to wave them off.  

All except for one time in a disco in Si Sa Ket, when I was sure I didn't see another soul in that bathroom when I walked in, and there I was, minding my own business when suddenly a pair a strong hands dug into my traps and I swear I let out a screech that must have sounded much like the noise that Jaime and Janney made when they found the spanking room at the Power Exchange.

So today, while using the restroom at In-N-Out, which actually is a shared restroom for the entire complex, which was not locked because they were painting the doors, I was standing there thinking "It's amazing that they don't build urinals facing the door - how have men put up with this sense of vulnerability for so many decades?"

And I realized - we take our personal urinal security very much for granted in this country.  We don't even know how much we have to be thankful for as U.S. citizens.  It's not everywhere in this world a man can pee in peace.

In the end, nobody touched me, and that was just the way I wanted it.  Four stars.  Out.
author: Joe C.

description:
This is where I discovered my love of burgers. I mean, I'd had them before, but there was no real love for them in my heart. In-N-Out changed that and there is no turning back. 

Anyway, for tourists: given McDonald's rapid and evil spread to most of the Earth, chances are, dear reader, that you've already tried and formed an opinion of burgers and other stereotypical American foods. And if you're anything like 98% of my Taiwanese acquaintance, you hate burgers. 

Trust me, McD's can't compare to In-N-Out and 7-11 hot dogs can't compare to Nathan's, either. It is so worth trying again. I mean, you spent all that money on a ticket to the states, you should at least try to get the whole American experience and have a burger. 

Don't be like my family. We drove all the way down to Mexico (from Seattle) once and for our big meal, we had ... Chinese food. We had CHINESE FOOD! IN MEXICO! how LAME is that?? 

Okay, so just go get yourself a burger already. You can eat at Panda Express for your next meal.
author: Kit S.

description: Must try protein style burger and animal style fries. This place was much better than regular fast food.
author: CY L.

description:
Can I just say what a big, whopping bummer it is that the cheapest, tastiest lunch in Fisherman's Wharf will expand your waistline in less time than it takes to write this review?

This installment of the monthly work lunch brought us to the heart of Touristlandia, where we scored a few nice tables outside.

I spent $5.35 on lunch today, which is no easy feat hereabouts. Even better, I came away completely satisfied. It would have been difficult not to, with a nice animal-style cheeseburger, some fries and a Diet Coke, my valiant attempt at calorie-cutting.

I give all In-n-Outs props for serving quality fast-food. Despite the obvious tubbs factor, everything is fresh and well-made. It's more than I can say for some unnamed places with frozen fries and burgers chillin' for an hour under the heat lamps.

I am running home today, in case there was any doubt.
author: Tara R.

description:
OMG.

So my friend rented a car on Saturday (after being denied by Zip Car because apparently she's a "high risk driver") and we proceeded to have a super San Francisco day.

This included a trip to Ocean Beach and us reading about "BRITNEY'S SUICIDE DRAMA."  Afterwards we spent like 20 minutes in traffic waiting to drive down Lombard St.  Good times.

The day ended with us deciding between eating at one of the sketch seafood restaurants in the Wharf (where the waiters have puffy shirts and serve shrimp cocktail) or going to In-N-Out Burger.

We chose In-N-Out.  I never come here because the Wharf sucks.  But if you need to consume an entire week's worth of calories in one sitting then I can't think of a better place.  Double-double animal style, fries and a chocolate shake.  This might be my last meal on Earth.

Seating sucks here.  Like a few different families were eyeing our table like vultures.  And of course they were foreign and kept looking at us and speaking with increasingly loud volume in a language I didn't understand.  Shame on me for being a stupid American.

Shame on In-N-Out for making me a stupid, FAT American.
author: Evan L.

description:
I love me a double double sauce only usually accompanied by animal style fries.  Sure its greasy and makes my face feel like I could butter toast by sliding a piece of bread across it but it's worth taking the chance of ruining my beautiful face.

Big ups to this location for letting Stormi and me in right before they close so we can get some life saving nourishment.  Sucks to be all those people that were trying to get in and had to watch us enjoying our delicious burgers while they were locked out in the cold.  Haha!
author: Luis M.

description:
I'm totally indifferent to In-N-Out.  Mainly because the fries taste like potato chips...bleh.

Minus one star because they don't ask for your name like the others do...and I like giving them fake names like Bambi, Boomquisha and Sunflower Rain.
author: Jay H.

description:
I know what you're thinking..
I want to go to Hooters to see the girls but I only have four dollars.  You're in luck my friend.  There is one table in the front corner of In-N-Out that gives you a clear view of the inside of hooters.  Now you can eat like the cheap-ass you are, and leer at 26 year olds like the pervy-ass you are.  boobs.
author: Patrick A.

description:
i hate tourists. there i said it. despite the fact that i love traveling to new places myself, and obviously don't enjoy being abused by the locals, i still see travelers to MY city as more of a nuisance than newcomers in need of support. i power down powell street with little to no remorse for the suitcase-carrying set in my way. i'm that girl that yells at first-time BARTers to "walk left, stand right!" - something that was somehow appropriate in the hustle and bustle of DC, but makes me seem like a jerk in the laid back bay area (i'm not, i swear; i'm just late!!). 

in line with my seething hatred of fanny packs, cheesy Hawaiian print shirts, and all other things tourist-related; i cannot stand fisherman's wharf. i'm sorry, but bubba gump's does not count as traditional SF fare, and there is absolutely nothing amazing about a bunch of sea lions just lying there. it reminds me of coney island with better weather but less rides and no awesome hot dogs. i just think there is so much more to this city than the dirty, crowded tourist trap known as fisherman's wharf. 

therefore, i pretty much only go to fisherman's wharf for two reasons. one, to indulge the whims of a friend from the east coast, and two, to indulge the whims of my stomach, with in 'n' out. it may be far, and infested with tourists, but it's still the best fast food on the planet.
author: Kris G.

description: Double double animal style.  That's all.  That's the whole review.  Just go to the counter and repeat those words, Double Double Animal Style.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Aaron K.

description: I love the burgers here, especially animal style! So delicious! The only thing i can say bad about here is that I got growled at by a homeless guy that was going threw their trash inside. Kinda wish they controlled that here.
author: Claudia M.

description: In & out always seems to be an amazing experience. Usually I go to the one in Daly City (super busy & long lines & wait time) but this past week I was at the pier and decided to go to this in & out. Nothing less then delightful, didn't wait long in line or to get my food. I went around 830pm I was surprised it wasn't too crowded. The boy calling out the orders, I believe his name was Anthony was exceptional at his job. Very kind, & even came around and threw away our trash for us with the best attitude. On top of a great burger and fries, the great customer service will definitely have me back. Say hello to a new loyal customer!
author: Hannah C.

description:
You would think that all In-N-Outs would have the same formula for making food, right?

This location consistently makes the freshest tasting food out of all of the In-N-Outs I've tasted. It makes it worth paying parking to come here. Perhaps it's the large volume that ensures fresh food?

Either way, every time I sink my teeth into that ground up cow on a bun, I pass through fresh, crispy lettuce and onion while fortified with that delicious ground beef and cheese. It can't be beat at this location. This is also the closest location to me! I'm about to go there now...

I just wish it wasn't near Fisherman's Wharf. What a pain in the ass.
author: Ryan V.

description:
If you like McDonald's...
...you will LOVE In-N-Out Burger 

(unless what you like about McDonald's is the browbeaten employees, skanky facilities, cultural vacuum, and general sense of institutional malevolence).
author: Beah B.

description:
Oh In-N-Out... How I love you so. But why do you have to be so close to my work and why do you have to stay open so late? I'm so hungry when I end my shift, don't you know? 

This location is open until 1am on weekdays and 1:30am on weekends. 

Da-da-da-DANGEROUS.
author: Jen D.

description:
When In-N-Out came to SF I was like OMG I love you!!!!! Just know this is located between the Wharf and Ghirardelli ( in plan words - tourist). Get ready for people who order slow and ask many I mean many many questions of the simplest menu ever. Just know it will be claustrophobic and you might divide and conquer ( one person orders the others stake out the dining area, and when a table opens up, you pounce on it.
But I love this place and go when I'm in a good mood and want that  burger and milkshake from heaven (OK maybe heaven but so good right) I pick here. Its cheap for that area and easy on the pockets.
author: Brandi R.

description:
Double-Double delicious! Fast food gets no better than this- simple, fresh and cheap.

Order it 'Animal Style'-slathered in mustard and onions on the grill!
Not for the timid.
author: Andy R.

description:
25 cents for each 6 minutes....1 hour limit....metered parking 7 days a week.....(if lucky enough to find parking).....tourists~!...tourists~! and more tourists~!......one should have expected on a sunny breezy day like this at the sf wharf...

longer than norm lines.....even longer wait for a meal....double double combo.....animal style burger~!....animal style fries~!....roar~~....feelin' such an animal....

quit hoverin'~!...people lurkin' over tables....ready to prance at an opennin'.....

same ol' good quality cheap burger meals...horrible location for sf locals....
author: Hen A.

description:
In-N-Out = Awesome no matter how many times you go, no matter what location, it pretty much always rules.

Just be aware at this location, the likelihood of a heart attack is higher, because the Bushman lies in wait.  He will get you every time.

*letsgototheoneonthewharf*
author: Lauren F.

description:
People of all sorts (kids, homeless people, lazy adults) come in and put their HANDS in the sliced lemon container, thus I never add any to my drinks.
-1star

We fight for parking with tourists to satisfy our munchies here whenever we're craving it. It does the trick.
+5stars
author: T L.

description:
To Do List:

1. 5-mile run: check
2. 1-hour weight session: check
3. Double-double, animal style fries, and a shake: check

Nothing says healthy like an delicious artery clogging meal after a good workout.

Simple menu, fresh ingredients, and service with a smile.

Useless fact of the day: Highest grossing In-N-Out is in Las Vegas, second highest grossing is in Barstow, CA (on the way to Vegas). I guess gamblers/drunkards love them some In-N-Out

Useless fact of the day part deux: Harry Snyder, the founder of In-N-Out, never advertised an In-N-Out location in a phone book. However, there was always a Harry Snyder listed with the address of the In-N-Out in that city.
author: Arin N.

description: The only in & out in san francisco to date is located in fisherman's wharf. Dependable and bargain prices, I would come here more often if it wasnt that far away. They close at 1am on weekends so a nice play to stop by for a snack after a night on along the pier. Ive never had a bad experience at In&out and this place is no exception. parking could be a problem though.
author: Robert Y.

description: I smell u every other day as I run past you.  1000 calories for a double double and shake is amazing for $5.
author: Fatty A.

description:
It's a burger. I'm not the biggest burger fan.  I have to admit- I don't crave it...don't like burger buns...

BUT, if I did-i'd be coo eating at an In N Out over the golden arches any day...well, almost any day..

in such a touristy spot, ya think they'd have more seating, or at least transportable chairs in the joint!
author: Jac T.

description: Animal style your burger. Grilled onions and pickles with extra sauce. Hell yes.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Maybe I'm missing something, or maybe I was just expecting too much from my first In-N-Out Burger experience... but I gotta say, it was pretty eh. 

Being that this was my first time, I placed my order with no alterations or add-ons from the infamous "secret" menu. I wanted to taste In-N-Out the way the fast food gods had intended. While the burgers are certainly tasty, and you can tell they're made fresh, I don't think I could ever go so far as to say it was the best I've ever had (and I've had a LOT of burgers in my time). The chocolate milkshake was a little too thick for my liking (like sipping soft serve ice cream through a way-too-thin straw), and the fries tasted doughy and undercooked. 

I'm glad I tried it, and I'd probably do it again... but I'd also be okay if I never came across another In-N-Out too.
author: Jocelyn C.

description:
At In-N-Out Burger you get the basics - done to perfection. The food is as fresh as possible. The service is quick as a bunny, and the prices are cheap as in inexpensive. 

Minus one star for the weenie sized patties. I always have to get a double. 

Minus one star for the cleanliness. This In-N-Out is perpetually hammered with customers, and it seems that they just don't get to the heavy lifting cleaning that is needed here.
author: Jim P.

description:
I am the only person I know who doesn't go ga-ga over In-N-Out Burger.  Truthfully, I don't think their burgers are all that.  Yes, I will eat them (I will never turn down a burger), but I'm not the one going "Oh, oh, we have to go."  Their burgers are simple.  Not the tastiest.  And I do not like their fries.  I much prefer McDonald's.  Yes, I love McDonald's fries.  Especially when their freshly fried and just a little tongue burning hot.

Anyway, In-N-Out satisfies the craving for a freshly made burger.
author: Denise M.

description:
"Fatty fatty 2 by 4, can't fit through the front door!"

Ok so I'm feeling a tad bit cantankorous today (read: bitchy!). Call it hormonal rage, call it pre-holiday meltdown, call it just feeling particularly snippy; no matter what you call it, I wasn't in the greatest of moods. Of course, when you're feeling like this, it's a fantastic time for the perfected simplicity of In-N-Out. Nothing better than adding to feeling cranky, run down and chunky then eating a burger and fries! Seriously, my tastebuds alert my endorphines, who kick in and beat the concept of calories out of my head.

Yes, we in CA are spoiled by many many exclusives and In-N-Out, I'm sure is in the top hundred list of the majority of Californians. Still if you are from the Bay Area, you can recall that this chain didn't come to the bay until the late '90's. Yep even fellow Californians were deprived! But then again that's what road trips are for (that and buying shakes to drink with the windows down and the heater up--oh wait that might be just me).

For those of you unfamiliar with the In-N- Out chain, the menu is simple. Hamburgers, cheeseburgers and the infamous Double Doubles (double meat, double cheese). They come with lettuce, tomatoes, thousand Island and onions. You can request grilled onions and pickles at no extra cost but of course, if you are "In-N-Out virgin" (heh heh-sorry love a good double entendre) the way to go is to go "Animal Style". I'm not even gonna go into what animal style entails but trust me, your friends at home will be impressed when you told them. If you like your burgers with no fuss but are still curious to try animal style you can get your fries that way instead. Feel a little better about the reckless abandonment of your waistline by knowing your food was cooked in vegetable oil.    

This location has its pros and cons. There is no drive through and its in Fisherman's Wharf area next to Hooters. It is as busy as pretty much any other In-N-Out but instead of an assortment of locals, there is a healthy representation of tourists and homeless. Still it's also one of the only places in the wharf area where you can lunch for around $5 and the quality is par with many other In-N-Out across the state. If you know your In-N-Out at all, you know you're happily paying for a place with standards and damn it, if you don't have standards why are you reading a review in the first place???  

(The burger and fries are gone now. I told you I was feeling bitchy.)
author: Veronica G.

description:
OK, so don't get me wrong, I love me some in-n-out. Cheese burger with grilled onions, fries, neapolitan shake, HELL YES! My gripe is not with in-n-out as a whole, as it is definitely a five-star establishment. But this one in particular? Not so hot.

This is the least-rad in-n-out I've been to. It's great that there is at least AN in-n-out in the city, but this place is always ridiculously crowded. Worst of all, there is NO DRIVE THROUGH! What the hell?!? This is the only in-n-out I've ever seen with no drive through. Oh yeah, and there's absolutely nowhere to park in the area.

So, maybe I'm being unfair. All in-n-outs are always ridiculously crowded. And oh yeah, I don't have a car...
author: Ben Y.

description:
Thank you In-N-Out for being the best damn burger chain there is. I get cravings for Animal Style 4x4's like a Tenderloin window washer craves the horse. When I get hungry I get really hungry too so the fact that I'm able to stack on as many patties as I want is definitely a plus (although I've never gone further than a 7x7). Animal style fries are delicious as well. The only reason this place lost a star is because it's located in fisherman's wharf, kind of out of the way for your average young SF resident. Either way I'll keep getting burger cravings and therefore keep coming back to In-N-Out.

Oh and one more plus is that they pay their employees well so you don't have to deal with a bunch of miserable slobs taking your order and making your food like at other burger chains.
author: Tommy P.

description:
I love In-N-Out.. but not *this* In-N-Out. 

Yeah, tourists are annoying, but they're vital to our economy. Yes, it's crowded, but ALL In-N-Outs are crowded. My problem is that the food really isn't as good at this one as it is at the Daly City store, and that this one just plain feels skanky. It's the dirtiest In-N-Out I have ever seen, and I can't go there without getting bombarded by beggars picking through the trash can, asking me to buy them a burger. I don't feel safe taking my son to this store.

I know all of it is because it is in Fishermans Wharf, which, as 'hoods go, is like the trashy relative no one invites to parties because they bring spam casserole and wear spandex.

When I get the craving, if I have my car, I'm for Daly City every time, and I try to avoid leaving the city in general for errands.

In-N-Out, why oh why can't you biuld a store IN the city for those of us who LIVE here, in a more desirable location? say, the Mission? Potrero? SOMA?
author: Rebecca S.

description: It's a shame...lol but after 7 months living in California I finally tried my first in-n-out burger...I was expecting a huge menu of burgers but.... nothing special... they do have few choices what makes easier to pick one... but the burger was very tasty....my friend from virginia just loved... :)
author: Bruna D.

description:
Five stars even though it's an insanely busy location.  Service has always been fine for me, even if I get a lil nervous they've forgotten about me with 24 other people waiting for food.

#2 grilled onions ONLY, mustard-fried patty, well-done
drink will be a Dr. Pepper, and I usually throw on extra salt on my fries

NOTE TO IGNORANT PEOPLE: NOTHING IS EVER FROZEN OR "HEAT-LAMPED" HERE. EVER.

If you're getting a shake, ask for Neopolitan--you know, vanilla+chocolate+strawberry--it's the best

I am biased because I worked for this company when I was a senior in high school (5+ years ago) and I still LOVE this company.
Employees get paid well and the company rewards them with huge picnics every year (at least in SoCal).  

And--the customer is always right. And in the event the customer is wrong, the customer is always right.
author: Robyn E.

description:
#1 burgers, fries (eat 'em QUICK) and shakes .... ANYWHERE.

... (small, ladilike) *burp* ...

... ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh ...

 ... z z z z z Z Z Z Z Z ...
author: Michael O.

description:
Ah, In-N-Out; the only reason I drag myself out of the Haight and up to Fisherman's Wharf.

After months of being too scared to order off of the "secret menu" for fear of being the butt of a cruel internet joke, I finally got up the courage and order my cheeseburger "animal style".

Heaven in a little paper wrapper!
author: Vanessa R.

description: I was in SF for work last week and was dragged here by a co-worker who had never been to In-N-Out. Such a horrible, tacky tourist location. But worse than that, the burgers are just so ridiculously obsessed about and fawned over, and they really just aren't that good. I've tried the regular cheeseburger, "animal style," alien style, and every other style, and sorry but they just don't do it for me. Don't get me started on how horrible the fries are. I'm thankful to In-N-Out for giving me something to chuckle about when I hear about crazies rushing straight here from SFO, or (and these people really need their sanity checked) having these nasty little burgers shipped to them in far-flung places. Sorry Californians, but In-N-Out just isn't all that.
author: Hugo C.

description:
Being that im from houston makes it even more agonizing that i can't have my favorite food any time i want. Anytime i do get the chance to come here, i salivate like a dog when i step into their restaurant. The burger and fries are that good that i wouldn't mind eating them daily to compliment my bulking regimen. 

As for the secret menu, if you aren't aware, just copy and paste the url below and you're all set for that adventure to in-n-out!

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In-N-Out_Burger_products#Secret_Menu_variations
author: Tony V.

description:
the comparisons have been made (in-n-out burger, five guys, shake shack) but the loyalists stick to favorites and therefore i'm sticking with shake shack.  many people rave about these burgers but the problem was that i could barely tell a burger was packed in the roll.  with so much lettuce, tomato and onion i needed to peel back the bun to see that i was actually eating a burger.  the one thing that is definitely superior to both five guys and shake shack is the bun.

favorites: if you've never had in-n-out, you should give it a try.  order the double patty.
author: Robert R.

description: Love these burgers. Yummy, moreish, quite small (but perfect size for me). Its fast food though, nothing fancy. Not that it claims to be but there were some disgruntled reviewers, maybe that's why?
author: CharlieLouis

description:
I'd heard people rave about In N Out Burger for years who said it was the best fast food they'd ever had. During my recent stay in San Francisco I headed on over to the restaurant to what they were talking about. 

I got a double double medium rare and some fries animal style. Even tried a milk shake. I wasn't that impressed really. It was just normal fast food. It didn't taste substantially better. The only thing they had going for them was the fact that you could customize your food in all kinds of crazy ways.

I'll probably never eat at this restaurant chain again if given the choice. There is much tastier much healthier food available in other places... Especially in San Francisco.
author: David M.

description:
I was rather excited to have my first In & Out burger the other day. Everyone raves about them and I like that they treat their staff well.

So I hopped on a bus and went down to the tourist hell that is Fisherman's Wharf. The place was certainly crowded enough and it's reassuring that you can see the burger being made.

But all in all when I got my hamburger and fries I was less than impressed. Yes, the meat tastes a lot better than McD's or Burger King, but there's not much of it. The roll was very cold and the sauce nothing to write home about.

The fries were very poor - they tasted floury and slightly stale and were below the standard of anything else I've had in the city. Maybe the secret menu style fries are better, but I'm not inclined the check.

The strawberry milkshake was however awesome. Real ice cream, nice taste and so thick you need a suction pump to get it up the straw - excellent.
author: Iain T.

description: The food is good when they make your order correctly.  But the wait here can be horrendous.  18 minutes from when you place your order until you get your food.  Might as well go to a sit down restaurant.
author: Paul K.

description:
Animal style. It's the only way. 

This location sucks, if you have a car, drive to the one in Daly City.
author: Maria D.

description:
I couldn't visit California without stopping by In-n-out..... and of course, as always, it didn't disappoint. This location is crowded (as expected), but the dining room is TINY. We had to take back our food to the hotel.... but by the time we weaved through the HUGE crowds down at Fisher-mans Wharf and got back the room or food was cold. 

But it was still amazing!
author: Cody R.

description:
Open late with a cheap and simple menu.
Employees treated well and it shows in the service.
French fries made out of entire potatoes before our eyes.
Secret items on the menu if one knows what to ask for.
Not even close to the best burger in the city, but for fast food, it's second to none.
author: Quinn S.

description:
In-N-out has nothing on What-A-Burger... but it's the best fast food chain in CA. 

Just be sure to ask for your fries "well done" or they'll be soggy... and if you're really feeling frisky ask for "Animal Style" both on your burger and your fries!
author: Thel D.

description: Burgers are amazing, just like any other in-n-out in the country. The location of the restaurant is fantastic. The only bad part (and this goes for the rest of the in-n-out's as well) is that huge line of customers, and the delay!!!
author: Gabriela U.

description: Because i was just in Ny and eating at Shake shack (wannabe in-n-out but really sub par) i feel the need to write this. i don't eat beef but the cheese sandwich with grilled onion is kinda great if you are a vegetarian. I'm sure it is hard to find parking in that area but somehow i always find it right across the street and it totally hits the spot at midnight when i'm craving it. I don't eat fast food but god do i love in-n-out. If you are from california you probably already love it and if you aren't i'm betting you want to come here to try it (so do)
author: sasha h.

description: Mmm double double deliciousness! Open late, right on the pier, awesome spot, awesome burgers!!
author: Chris J.

description:
Crowded place, but somehow the hamburger making machinery hums right along.

Forgot how good those In-N-Out Burgers are.  Yum!
author: Jens J.

description:
Why would they have an In-N-Out Burget in a tourist trap area? The prices are actually reasonable to those in the suburbs and regular fast food joints.

My favo is #3 with grilled onions and regular fries. Don't bother me if you ask for Animal style.. my heart is pumping and those trans fat are starting to block my arteries... can't even spell it... need to go to the restroom.
author: Wilson L.

description:
i love the food here.  this location is what you'd expect - constantly busy, kinda dirty, not enough seating.  I think it's almost always the case that In-N-out has more people in the restaurant than seats but this place seems especially jammed with tourists (duh, it's Fisherman's wharf).  It's also, unfortunately, the only location in SF :(.   

Get the neopolitan shake (the flavors stay separated! it's great if you're indecisive at picking ice cream flavors)
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I love In-N-Out. Yes, most of us do.

But. I was once spotted having a double-double, 2 fries and a coke at 10am on a Saturday morning. Yes, I was the first customer in there *and* this was after a 20-miler in preparation for a marathon.

That's how much I love In-N-Out.
author: Frederic B.

description:
Overall, this is a great place!
And it's open really late, until 1am!!!

The burgers are a little overrated, but I still like them.
The secret codes (3x3, protein style, animal style, etc.) are just silly.
Yes, I did think that the codes were fun when I was in high school.
Also McDonald's fries are better.
author: George M.

description:
Normally, I wouldn't recommend fast food to anyone I think deserves a clean artery. However, I can't seem to shun In-N-Outthey've sucked me into the fast food vortex.


 However, In-N-Out has a better reputation than McDonalds and Burger King. Their meat products are of a higher quality, and they don't add sugar and excessive additives to their food. For that reason, I justify eating the occasional double-doublewith fries and a soda, of course.


 Don't forget the SECRET MENU when you visit:


 3-by-3 is three meat patties and three slices of cheese.


 4-by-4 is four meat patties and four slices of cheese.


 2-by-4 is two meat patties and four slices of cheese.


 You can get a burger with as many meat patties or cheese slices as you want.


 Double Meat is like a Double Double without cheese.


 3 by meat is three meat patties and no cheese.


 Animal Style is when the meat is cooked and fried with mustard and then pickles are added, extra spread and grilled onions are added.


 Animal Style Fries is fries with cheese, spread, grilled onions and pickles.


 Protein Style is a burger with no bun and instead wrapped in lettuce.


 Flying Dutchman is two meat patties, two slices of melted cheese and no bun


 Fries Well-Done is simply extra crispy fries.


 Fries Light is the opposite of fries well-done.


 Grilled Cheese is no meat, just melted cheese, tomato, lettuce and spread on a bun.


 Veggie Burger is a burger without the patty or cheese.


 Neapolitan Shake is strawberry, vanilla and chocolate ice cream blended together.
author: sfKristina

description:
It is what it is. Is it gourmet? Of course not. Are there better burgers in the city? Of course.

But it is damn filling, and the quality is great for fast food. I love how you get to see them cut and slice the potatoes right there in front of you, and it will fill you up without you feeling disgusting for not very much.
author: Mark A.

description: Night shift did not show a very professional manner of behaviour. I personally don't care what you're laughing about but if your order is taking longer that usual and the customer behind you who orders more than what you ordered it and display unprofessional behaviour while I wait is a unacceptable in my view. To add on top of that, to get an order of animal style fries spilled over just only fuels a customers patience. I was not impressed with the workflow and productivity with the amount of employees working with having customers working. I've seen employees working harder in the millbrae and daly city branch work harder and show better professionalism than what I've seen. All I have to say is to be cautious of who is working the late shift at this location.
author: Pablo P.

description: I'm not sure what the fuss is all about...if there was a Five Guys across the street this place would be closed in a week.  Yes, its a chain and I get that, but Five Guys is way better than this place.
author: Greg N.

description: This is probably one of the most accessible In n Out joints to take out of town friends to. Fries, double double, & smoothies, all great things to chat about when you leave the west coast and find yourself stuck in a college dorm in NE.
author: Adam X.

description:
I have never been one of the in-and-out cultists but I do believe that the burgers here are pretty good.  In my humble opinion I think that the really key element is the buns that are toasted in butter.... that and the grilled onions.

This incarnation of in-and-out isn't better of worse than any other.  They all are equally as frustrating as you have to put on your hawk look to get a  seat.  The tables are never really clean.  It seems to take forever to get your food too... All that being said it is pretty cheap and decent.

Get the fries extra crispy. It makes a huge difference.
author: Thadd L.

description:
WEIGHT WATCHERS BEWARE!!! 

Once you have eaten an In-N-Out burger, you may drop the diet and go on an In-N-Out burger diet. Yes, they are that good!! 

I love the double-double with fries. Their food is so fresh and tasty. The chocolate milk shack is a bit disappointing. I've had it several times, I kept hoping it would somehow improve overtime. Nope!!

GULP!!!  BREATH!!!! I'm about ready to share a secret. By sharing the following information the In-N-Out Burger Secret Service may arrest me so please, use some discretion with this info. Well, if they do arrest me maybe they will feed me In-N-Out burgers everyday.  I'm going to risk it all and share with you the "not-so-secret menu". Yes, they have such a thing! You can find it on their website at: http://www.in-n-out.com/secretmenu.asp 

There, I've done it!! I've told the whole Yelping community about the secret! ENJOY!!!!!
author: Eric R.

description:
OMG..
i worked here for over a year..
and NEVER got sick of the food..
DBLDBL SLO X WHGR FRD-MSTD P MD-RARE
DBLDBL ANIMAL X WHGR INSTD T O P MD-RARE
which are both basically the same thing :D
double double with spread, lettuce, onion & extra whole grilled onion, with fried mustard no pickle, medium rare.

of course i would make a complicated order.. HAHA 

the wait time never exceeds 8 mins.. not including the time you have to wait in line.. but once your order's in.. it takes between 5-8 minutes.. TRUST ME.. i remember constantly having to monitor the wait time.. 

recently.. they hired a bunch a younguns that are too cool for customer service.. and it shows.. rollilng their eyes.. inattentive to all customers.. no smiles.. 

oh yea.. and if you have even the slightest problem with your food. go and complain.. because they have to remake it for you if you ask.. HAVE TO.. :)

can you tell i hated working there?
author: monica c.

description:
Of all the fast food places, it really does not get better than In-N-Out. Freshly cut and made fries and made-to-order burgers that don't skimp on the veggies. I'm not a huge fan of this location since it is near the wharf and feels way too touristy, not to mention more expensive than other In-N-Outs around the Bay Area, but I still come to this one because it's the only one in the city. 

I always get well-done fries - I have never gotten it any other way, though I've tried it with animal-style and it was a bit much with an animal-style cheeseburger. I think it will stand great on its own as an unhealthy snack. 

For this location, come at off meal hours so you're guaranteed a table, or else you might have to sit outside. Just watch out for hungry and aggressive seagulls, they are not afraid of humans.
author: K. E.

description:
In N Out Burger is fast food, no question there. As fast food though, In N Out Burger is in a league of it's own.

It's not clasy, it's no stylish, but then again what fast food establishment is. The 1950s facade they carry is a plus, but that's not what  Ilove about the place.

The burgers, the fries, the shakes, everything is from fresh ingredients, freshly made and delicious. Sure, there are many other places one can go to eat and probably get better food. Soemtimes, though, sometimes you just want fast food. For that, nothing beats IN N Out Burger; it is my White Castle.
author: Keith M.

description:
I decided yesterday that maybe I won't make this In-N-Out Burger location a family destination when we're visiting TouronLand  (aka "The Wharf") in SF any more. It's mostly that it takes too long, and the fries were limp, and I'm starting to feel panic in crowds these days for some reason, maybe since witnessing that shooting a few weeks ago.

The concept is nice, though, and I do enjoy their burger. Bargain-basement prices are always a good quality in a fast food meal.
author: Chiquita y.

description:
When I first moved here I searched high and low for this place.  Being from So. Cal. we had them in adundance.  Seeing as I don't mess around when it comes to matters of the heart, I finally had to get on the horn and ask for directions.  No joke there is an 800 number and I was on the 80 when I had to use it.  I don't even remember where it was they directed me to, but I know it took me about 30 minutes to get back.  

Fast forward a few months, I'm at the Fisherman's Wharf, and what do I see?  Yeah, you guessed it, and In-N-Out!!  What??  You mean I had one literally right under my nose and I was somewhere in San Leandro in a drive through?  Madness!!  So now I know, and now I've come, seen, and conquered (a.k.a eaten)...

The things you do for one of these yummy burgers and milkshakes...I'll take one cheeseburger, one hamburger, two fries, and one vanilla milkshake and MAKE IT SNAPPY!

P.S. That's what a hamburger is ALL ABOUT!!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Oh... how I wish there was one in Michigan!

I've been lucky enough to eat this nummy stuff on 3 different occasions.  I am going to have to convince my yelp-obsessed cousin from the bay area to fly me a bag-o-goodies when she visits in August.

Besides that, I don't really need to say much, just read the 250+ reviews.
author: Theresa U.

description: My favorite meal when I was in San Francisco and also the cheapest! Had the burger and fries animal style which is the best way to go. This place is busy, but you kinda have to figure it's going to be because of the location. LOVE this place!
author: James H.

description:
First off... why in God's name did I read this review an hour and a half before my lunch-break? BAD THINKING.

Anyway, you know what In N Out is all about, and this one doesn't strike me as being all that different from the other 10 or so locations I've visited. I do have a couple complaints though...

Despite INO's massive popularity, which assures that there's going to be a wait at almost any time of day, most of their locations handle the onslaught pretty well. This location seems to be lagging though... even when it's a quiet, mid-week night around 10:30PM. This puzzles me, because I specifically visit during such hours to avoid the monumental lines.

I also don't like the lack of an on-site bathroom here. There's a common bathroom across the courtyard, but it's locked (and surprisingly unclean in spite of being locked). Plus, having to hassle one of the counter people for a token can be difficult to do in light of their attentiveness to the customers placing their orders. 

Oh well. It's still damn good fast food, and the staff seems to be really genuinely friendly.
author: Alex C.

description:
+5 stars for the fact that their food is DELICIOUS!

-3 stars for the woman who wiped her snot all over her hands after sneezing, and then proceeded to hand us our tray of food.

... Please. Wash your hands.
author: Thea G.

description: MMM, the burgers were good and the service was fast. Being in Fisherman's Wharf you wanted the seafood but for a burger, this is the place to go
author: Raul M.

description: They must put crack in the cheeseburger sauce because I was craving for more as soon as I took my first bite. Maybe it's a good thing we don't have these on the East Coast. Otherwise, I'll be another statistic for reports on obesity.
author: Amy C.

description:
Growing up in the Bay Area, In-N-Out was something you ate on a trip down to LA. High schoolers would wear the t-shirts to prove they went to the Southland over spring break. They alter the stickers to read "In-N-Out URGE." (Meanwhile, the family that owns the chain is devoutly Christian, so they stamp Bible verses on the containers.) It's family-owned. The "secret menu" has more things on it than the real menu - which is really just hamburger, cheesburger, double cheeseburger (Double Double), fries, sodas, and shakes. Even though it's fresher and tastier than major chain fast food, it's cheaper. So there's a mystique to the place, but it's for a reason (or two).

Now when I lived in LA, I was really more a fan of Fatburger, but I'm glad that there's an In-N-Out on the Wharf. Tourists like it, and I like it when tourists are at the Wharf, because that means they're spending money and they're not in my neighborhood. Those who complain about the crowds at this location obviously haven't been to many In-N-Outs - they're ALWAYS crowded. Try the Kettleman City location on I-5 if you don't believe me.

Read the other reviews to find links to the "secret menus" posted on the web.
author: Timothy O.

description:
Now you know what I love about this place?  The beggars hanging out outside.  Just kidding.

What I really like about this place is their super secret menu.  Do you know you can order a 10 by 10?  That's ten patties and ten slices of cheese for you n00bs.  My friend says he finished one, and I believe him, cause he's the guy I that ordered the whole menu with me at top-dog.

I remember when we did that, I lied in bed wondering if it was gonna be the last night of my life.

Luckilly, I got up in the morning and had a few glasses of water and I was fine.
author: Rocco B.

description:
I HATE visiting Fisherman's Warf with a passion.

Pretty much my only exceptions are taking visiting friends (that refuse to do anything else until you take them) and In 'n Out.

I get the same thing every time, because, let's face it, there aren't a whole lot of options here, people.  Double Meat, no spread, ketchup instead with grilled onions, fries and a Dr. Pepper.

Heaven.

I LOVE that all the ingredients are fresh and never frozen.  You can see them making the fries from real potatoes!  I love this company in general because it's completely family owned!  Not a single franchise!

I've had some pretty memorable experiences at this In 'n Out and I'll always go back and wait in the massive long lines of tourists to have them.
author: B C.

description:
Clutch. Delicious. Cheap. Convenient. 

Get a chocolate milkshake :)
author: linda t.

description:
I have to admit I love the juicy double double cheeseburger + one order of French fries + Dr. Pepper once in a while.  

I would recommend this place to anyone who happens to fall into the following categories.

1. After demanding physical activity (skiing, surfing, hiking, endurance training, hard manual labor, etc..)

2. Morning hangover crowd (those who had one too many drinks the night before).

3. You're coming off a fast or severe caloric restriction of some type (think 14+ hour fast for blood work).

I think this is where it stops...  

A double double, French fries and dr. pepper is 1200+ cals :-) 

Unless you're Pittsburgh/Ohio construction, mining, hard manual labor type it's just way too dense. 

Just my two cents but the place is a weakness of mine too.  :-(
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: This location is not one of the best, the ones in the East Bay are far better. However, I am a huge fan...perhaps even a groupie of In-out-Out. I pray every day that they will go national because nobody can compete in terms of price or quality IMHO.
author: Finn K.

description:
IN-N-OUT BURGER IS MY FAVORITE BURGER IN THE WORLD!!!
It's the only place were I like my hamburgers! They have a secret formula that blows you away. They also have great shakes and french fries.
I TRULY RECOMMEND THIS PLACE!
author: Nina C.

description:
Nothing finishes off a drunken day into night than In-IN-Out.
made our way down here at about  who knows when. The group including "The Lady" grubbed on cheese burgers and animal fries. 
 YUM!
author: Douggers M.

description:
The burgers, fries, and shakes are 3 stars, certainly not exceptional, but still a very good fast food burger and fries. The shakes are great. The value bumps this review up to 4 stars. 

Not sold on the Animal style hype, it made everything way too messy and I couldn't taste as much of the beef as I wanted. I liked the fries, though can see why others hate them.
author: Steve J.

description: Always good. If you're out West and see an In N Out, do yourself a favor and get a double double, fries, and a shake. Classic.
author: Mike M.

description:
Good Food, Bad People, Bad People

Tourist hell.  Makes for a unique experience.  

Last time I was there this white trash couple with a little girl tried to cut the pecking order for seating.  Karma man, karma.  The mother had this half shirt on showing her large pregnant stomach and her stretched out tattoo of a butterfly.  I immediately threw up in my mouth.  Now I'm ready to eat.  Then they proceed to tag the booth and leave all their trash on the table.  Way to set a good example for your daughter.  SCUM BAG!

By the way, the foods just like any other In-N-Out.  Just try to keep your food down at this location.

****Check out the secret menu below****

MENU
Double Double
Cheese Burger
Hamburger
Fries
Drink
  Shake - Chocolate, Strawberry & Vanilla
  Other - Coke, D. Coke, Dr. Pepper, 7-UP, Root Beer, Lemonade, Coffee

SECRET MENU
Grilled Cheese - a cheeseburger without the burger
Animal Style Burger - Mustard cooked beef patty, more pickles, extra secret sauce with grilled onions.
Animal Style Fries - French fries with secret sauce, onions and cheese on top.
Light or Well Done fries - Limp or extra crispy fries?
Protein Style - Whatever burger you ordered wrapped in lettuce instead of a bun
Flying Dutchman - 2 patties, 2 pieces of cheese, that it
3 x 3 - 3 patties and 3 slices of cheese, try a 10 x 10
2 x meat - No cheese and 2 patties, try a 10 x meat
2 x 4 - 2 patties and 4 slices of cheese
Extra Toast - toast your bun longer for a crispy experience
Neopolitan Shake - Strawberry, vanilla and chocolate together not blended
Peppers - Ask for them when you pick up if you want something spicy
author: Po L.

description: Counter guy was hilarious.  I told him this was my first In-N-Out burger, and he said "Dude, youre gonna love it!".  Got the double double animal style which was fantastic.  I am docking a star though - the fries were just average, and no bathroom so I had to wander off searching for one - but it took so long for my order that I still had ten minutes of waiting after I got back.
author: Jack F.

description:
Open late night, easy parking after 8pm, great burgers and awesome fries. This place is hard to beat for the money. Be sure to check your order before you leave though.

Fast friendly service too. I've had the shakes and recommend them if you want to top off your feast with some frozen goodness.

Double Double with Fries and chocolate shake. Yummy.
author: Jeff W.

description:
This place is great. Just don't come by during the rush hours. Came in here today and got my order taken care of right away. Tastes the same as the other In n Outs. 

Good luck finding a seat though!
author: Zack L.

description:
Ok - I was born in California, I live here currently, and I just had my first In-N-Out Burger. You see, where I have been living most of my life is Seattle - and we have Dick's burgers there. And while I am partial to the Seattle landmark, I had to try the California one. 
It was ok. being at the Fisherman's Warf is a major downfall for me. And driving all the way toward San Jose to go to the other local spot was out of the question. I should start by saying I HATE tourist's like they were my arch enemies. No really, I hate them so so much. Pushy- rude people trying to special order everything on the menu while you constantly have to remind yourself to be polite and wait for them to finish without yelling expletives. This In-N-Out is smack dab in tourist central and there was a line of people waiting to get their order.
The staff here is pretty fun to watch. They run the place like a machine. That food comes out of this place like a Ford model T. It's pretty impressive. Our food took no time. 
The chocolate shake - tastes just like McDonald's
The Double burger - outrageously messy, but VERY tasty and fresh
The Fries - Well, I had to re-heat them when I got home and they needed some seasoning, but pretty good for fresh fries (I hate to admit I prefer frozen)

Overall - it's good. But not THAT good. For the prices - I'll go back to a different location next time and review it again later.
author: Jena D.

description: Ever since In-N-Out came to SF it's been our Valentine dinner spot. We always went to the one in Daly City so we could have Krispy Kreme for dessert. This year, since we moved closer to the wharf, we decided to try that one. BIG MISTAKE.  The tables weren't cleaned, they dropped our order so we had to wait at the back of the line and there is no bathroom on the premises. Instead, go outside, down an alley and down stairs in the hopes of not being mugged in the process.  Also, soggy fries and half of my bun was missing.  It's better to drive further to get the quality that In-N-Out has been known for since the 40's.
author: anne l.

description:
I felt like most everyone I talked to prior going to In-n-Out overhyped the place for me.....

...therefore, I felt a bit disappointed when I finally went today for dinner. Food was fresh, and I was impressed to see that, yes, they make their fries out of real, fresh potatoes (saw them cutting up the potatoes in the back).

However, the food was okay; nothing super-stellar. Reminded me of Five Guys from back east. Seemed overhyped in general. I was expecting more variety I guess. Also, the strawberry milkshake was a bit too sweet for me.

Will probably eat here again, but I guess I also partially set myself up for a little disappointment since I expected more (I guess I expected something like Fuddrucker's....).
author: Helene K.

description:
In-n-out burger... i love you."

while their burgers may be on the small side, and the meat may be on the small side, the taste of their burgers are second to none.

some people also complain about their fries not being like mcdonalds, or what have you... all i can say is that they are fresh cut potatoes, without all the processing that happens with other fast food restaurant fries.... taste pretty darn good to me!

finally, i highly recommend at some point in your in-n-out burger dining experiences to try a cheese burger, plain.  just the bun, meat, and cheese.  its fantastic!  the bun is so soft and fresh, the cheese and meat tastes awesome!
author: shaun l.

description:
Okay... there are better burgers.  I am not talking the $20 Ritz B.S. or stuff like that... I just mean little mom and pops around the world.

Like the Apple Pan in LA
http://www.yelp.com/biz/odzvOMZgp0OVYGp9sDS3qQ

Best this is by far the best chain burger on the planet, I believe they were the first drive thru in the world as well.  They are fresh, never frozen (that goes for everything), and it is so fun to sit there and watch the uniform chaos that is so well controlled and maintained in a raucous assembly line fashion.  

I like watching the potatoes get diced.  It has got to be some freaky horror show to be a potato watching your friends get hacked into little bits.  But if they knew how delicious they were.... I am sure they wouldn't mind.

Thank goodness potatoes don't scream though.  Well.. sometimes.  But that is only in my mind.  I am half blind in my mind anyhoo.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
As always, their burgers are my favorite.
I taks about 15 minutes for my order to be ready.. everytime i'm there.
Can't say its not worth it though. 
This location is overall clean. Once in a while there would be homeless sitting around or asking for change. 
Besides that, my order of double cheeseburger with animal fries are the BOMB!
author: Paula Z.

description: Loved the burger little disappointed in the fries.  I have been waiting to go to an In-N-Out Burger for years now and I was not disappointed.  Ill be back!
author: Rick A.

description:
OMG ! omg! everyone goes insane as if theyre having a seizure, when you mention in&out! well, i do! just thinking about their burgers makes me want one so. bad. right. now! NOW! 

other people are great fans of it but i dont like the fries. it's too raw for me. i asked for them to cook it more. 
youll pretty much always have to wait. the wait time is def longer than McD's or burgerking.. but you get the better quality as well! I WISH THEY BUILT ANOTHER ONE somewhere else in the city!! close to where I LIVE!! i dont exactly want to make the trip all the way to the wharf area just for burgers. hm.
author: Veranna N.

description:
The burgers at In-N-Out really are the best fast food burgers I have ever had.  I was pretty much the only one of my friends to never have had one.  So this was my first visit and I just loved it.  I had my fiance order for me and we both got a burger and fries (both animal style).  My only regret was not getting a milkshake.  I hear they are pretty darn good.

On the other hand, this place was packed and it took a good 5 minutes before our orders were complete.  Who cares though, it was so worth the wait.
author: Cathy S.
